definition.primary: Abnormal focal dilatation of the carotid artery to greater than 150% of normal diameter, classified as true aneurysms (involving all arterial wall layers) or pseudoaneurysms (contained rupture with adventitial or periarterial tissue wall).
key_concepts: True aneurysms involve all three arterial wall layers (intima, media, adventitia)
Pseudoaneurysms result from vessel wall disruption with blood contained by surrounding tissue
Classification by location: extracranial (cervical) vs intracranial
Etiology includes atherosclerosis, infection (mycotic), trauma, dissection, fibromuscular dysplasia, and post-surgical

epidemiology.prevalence: Rare, representing less than 1% of all arterial aneurysms
epidemiology.demographics: Male predominance, typically presenting in 5th-7th decade
epidemiology.trends: Increasing detection with widespread use of cross-sectional imaging

primary_causes.description: Most common cause of true extracranial carotid aneurysms, typically fusiform morphology
Following blunt or penetrating neck trauma, often presents delayed
Bacterial seeding of arterial wall, typically Staphylococcus or Salmonella species
Aneurysmal degeneration following carotid dissection with intramural hematoma
Associated with medial fibroplasia pattern, often bilateral

symptoms: Cranial nerve compression (dysphagia, dysphonia, Horner syndrome)

imaging.utility: Initial screening, demonstrates flow characteristics and size
Gold standard for anatomic characterization, extent, and surgical planning
Alternative when CT contraindicated, excellent for dissection evaluation
Definitive assessment when intervention planned, evaluates intracranial circulation

surgical_options.applicability: Fusiform aneurysms, uses autogenous vein (GSV) or prosthetic
High-lying aneurysms not amenable to direct reconstruction

endovascular_options.applicability: Saccular aneurysms in favorable anatomy, pseudoaneurysms
Pseudoaneurysms with narrow neck, often combined with stenting

outcomes.natural_history: Without treatment, stroke risk estimated at 50% over 5 years in symptomatic patients

learning_objectives: Classify carotid aneurysms by etiology and morphology
Recognize clinical presentations suggesting carotid aneurysm
Select appropriate imaging modality for diagnosis and planning
Determine indications for surgical versus endovascular intervention
Understand the natural history and treatment outcomes
key_points: Extracranial carotid aneurysms are rare but carry significant stroke risk
Atherosclerosis is the most common etiology in older patients
Thromboembolism is the primary mechanism of stroke, not rupture
CTA is the gold standard for preoperative planning
Treatment approach depends on anatomy, etiology, and patient factors
clinical_pearls: Always evaluate for bilateral disease, especially in FMD
Mycotic aneurysms require prolonged antibiotics and debridement of infected tissue
High-riding aneurysms may require mandibular subluxation for surgical exposure
Endovascular covered stents have limited durability data in this location

references.evidence_basis: Clinical practice guidelines and case series

key_citations.description: Systematic review of surgical outcomes for extracranial carotid aneurysms
